docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton made an election-year promise to appoint a panel that would address consumer anxieties about the quality of medical care in an era of market-driven health plans. Whatever its purpose as a campaign ploy, the commission, appointed yesterday, could not come at a better time. Politicians are littering Capitol Hill with bills, many of which reflect nothing more than vested interests seeking advantage in this trillion-dollar industry. Some bills would dictate how many chiropractors health plans would be required to hire. Some would impose controls on profit. Others would set down criteria for hiring and firing doctors or lengths of stay for surgery on specific body parts. What Congress needs from the panel is a blueprint for the role of government in a market dominated by managed care.

docs.lead_paragraph: Reversing its position, the National Cancer Institute said today that women in their 40's should have breast X-rays every one to two years. The cancer institute also advised women at increased risk of breast cancer for any of a variety of reasons, including having a genetic mutation that predisposes them to develop breast cancer or having their first child after age 30, to seek guidance from their doctors on how often to have such mammograms and whether to start before age 40.

headline.main: Another Group Switches on Frequency of Mammograms

docs.abstract: National Cancer Institute reverses position and recommends that women in their 40's have breast X-rays every one to two years; also advises women at increased risk of breast cancer for any reason, including genetic predisposition, to seek medical guidance on starting mammograms before age 40; says regular mammograms can reduce death rate by 17 percent in this group; Pres Clinton hails recommendations and will urge insurance companies to pay for tests; recent controversies over mammogram recommendations reviewed (S)
docs.snippet: Reversing its position, the National Cancer Institute said today that  women in their 40's should have breast X-rays every one to two years.     The cancer institute also advised women at increased risk of breast cancer for any of a variety of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officials and several Government agencies are investigating an array of business practices at the nation's largest health care company, the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, which runs about 350 hospitals and treats 125,000 people a day. The Government's scrutiny of Columbia came to light last week in a Federal criminal investigation of Columbia operations in El Paso. In a raid of Columbia hospitals and doctors' offices, agents with search warrants carted off truckloads of billing and medical records. The inquiry appears, at least in part, to involve the company's dealings with Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly.

headline.main: Biggest Hospital Operator Attracts Federal Inquiries
headline.kicker: HEALTH CARE'S GIANT: Powerhouse Under Scrutiny -- A special report.

docs.abstract: Special report, Health Care's Giant, on Government investigations of business practices at nation's largest health care company, Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, which runs about 350 hospitals and treats 125,000 people a day; Federal agents have raided hospitals and doctors' offices in El Paso, carting off truckloads of billing records; Health Care Financing Administration chief Bruce Vladeck reports review of 'upcoding,' in which hospitals inflate seriousness of illnesses to get higher Medicare payments; civil and criminal investigators also probe referrals by Columbia doctors to medical services in which they have interests; yearlong investigation by The New York Times finds Columbia hospitals submit more and higher bills than comparable institutions, with extra Medicare payments of nearly $50 million in Texas alone in 1995; company, less than ten years old, controls seven percent of nation's hospitals, mostly in Sunbelt; Columbia is Medicare's single largest biller, and Medicare money makes up 36 percent of company revenue; analyses of high billings by Columbia Spring View Medical Center in Kentucky and Cedars Medical Center in Miami detailed; graph; practice of encouraging doctors to invest in hospitals where they practice also probed (L)
docs.snippet: Law enforcement officials and several Government agencies are investigating an array of business practices at the nation's largest health care company, the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, which runs about 350 hospitals and treats 125,000 people...

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

byline.original: By Martin Gottlieb, Kurt Eichenwald and Josh Barbanel

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton today appointed a 34-member advisory panel to draft a bill of rights for health care consumers and to assess the need for the Federal Government to regulate private health insurance plans. The panel immediately came under fire from House Republicans like Representative Bill Thomas of California, who denounced it as ''a politically inspired gimmick designed to ratify'' further regulation of the health care market. Mr. Thomas heads the Health Subcommittee of the Ways and Means Committee.

headline.main: Clinton Names Panel to Draft Health Consumer Bill of Rights

docs.lead_paragraph: A leading candidate for ambassador to France has withdrawn, tired of waiting for the call from the White House. There is no American ambassador in important countries, like Russia, Japan and Germany. And many top jobs under Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright await appointees. Two months into President Clinton's second term, the selection of the senior diplomatic corps has bogged down, a victim of White House indecision caused in part by the furor over campaign financing.

headline.main: NAMING OF ENVOYS SLOWS TO A CRAWL

docs.abstract: Two months into Pres Clinton's second term, selection of senior diplomatic corps has bogged down, victim of White House indecision caused in part by furor over campaign financing; with Administration under scrutiny for favors that it may or may not have granted donors to 1996 Presidential campaign, White House lawyers are scrutinizing backgrounds of potential nominees for anything that might drag Clinton into new controversy; Frank G Wisner, Ambassador to India, has withdrawn from consideration to be ambassador to France, tired of waiting for call from White House; there is no American ambassador in important countries like Russia, Japan and Germany; many top jobs under Sec of State Madeleine K Albright await appointees (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Legislation to expand Medicare coverage of preventive health services is all the rage on Capitol Hill as Republicans and Democrats trumpet the value of tests to detect breast cancer, prostate cancer, diabetes and other diseases. But behind the scenes, lobbyists are waging a shadowy, fierce battle to win the Government's imprimatur for some tests while denying coverage for others. At stake are millions of patients' lives and billions of dollars in revenues for doctors and medical-supply companies.

headline.main: Backers of Rival Health Tests Fight to Get Medicare Dollars

docs.abstract: Lobbyists play key role in debate in Congress over which preventitive health services Medicare should cover; their efforts on behalf of competing tests for colorectal cancer show how Congress grapples with such issues, which raise complex questions of science, economics and politics and can affect policies of private insurers as well (M)
docs.snippet: Legislation to expand Medicare coverage of preventive health services is all the rage on Capitol Hill as Republicans and Democrats trumpet the value of tests to detect breast cancer, prostate cancer, diabetes and other diseases.    But behind the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Lisa Kay Standard struggled to lift herself out of her long green canoe as it nosed onto the white sandy beach on this tangle of mangroves and palmettos on the edge of the Everglades. At first, her legs failed her, as they often do. But with an extra heave the 26-year-old woman pitched forward and was finally able to step ashore. For nearly two years, Ms. Standard, who was forced to give up her job as a first-grade teacher because of a degenerative disease akin to muscular dystrophy, has been walking with ankle-to-knee leg braces and a cane and, for longer distances, riding a motorized wheelchair.

headline.main: Insurers Turn To Retraining Injured Workers

docs.abstract: Disability insurers are engaged in aggressive but successful drive to boost earnings by rehabilitating and retraining injured workers in face of fall-off in profits over past decade, as companies liberalized policies to attract more customers, and as claims have multiplied; industry, facing long-term drag on earnings, has determined that making money depends on successful management and retraining of injured workers; have established programs with corporations to get disabled employees back to work, particularly those with advanced education and special skills; more and more corporations are demanding good return-to-work programs, arguing that they save money in recruiting and retraining and prevent losses in productivity; disability program run by Hartford Life Insurance Company described; photos; charts; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans said it would begin letting members visit specialists directly rather than forcing them to first seek referrals from family doctors. The plan will work much like preferred provider organizations, which offer managed-care members the chance to choose family doctors and specialists from a list. The operator of health maintenance organizations said it would form rosters from which its members may choose specialists.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton will soon propose new steps to crack down on health care fraud, following the discovery that many doctors still receive Medicare payments after their licenses have been revoked or they have been expelled from Medicare for professional misconduct. Administration officials said Mr. Clinton would announce the legislative proposals in a ceremony at the White House on Tuesday.

headline.main: Clinton to Offer New Steps to Eliminate Fraud in Health Care

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton will soon propose new steps to crack down on health care fraud, following discovery that some doctors still receive Medicaid payments after their licenses have been revoked, or they have been expelled from Medicare for professional conduct (M)
